description: From Middle English schrynken, from Old English sċrincan, from Proto-Germanic *skrinkwaną. Cognate with Dutch schrinken (“to shrink”).
The sense “psychologist, psychotherapist” is a clipping of head-shrinker.

entries.meaning: (slang, sometimes derogatory) A psychiatrist or psychotherapist.
examples: You need to see a shrink, you crazy fool.
My shrink said that he was an enabler, bad for me.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, business) Loss of inventory, for example due to shoplifting or not selling items before their expiration  date.
examples: Assuming the retailer's shrink is average or below, and the owner is comfortable with the level of shrink, perhaps nothing more need be done except to maintain vigilance and to monitor the shrink for signs of emerging problems.

verbs.description: shrink (third-person singular simple present shrinks, present participle shrinking, simple past shrank or shrunk, past participle shrunk or shrunken)

examples: This garment will shrink when wet.
Molly shrank away from the blows of the whip.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figuratively) To withdraw or retire, as from danger.
examples: They assisted us against the Thebans when you shrank from the task.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move back or away, especially because of fear or disgust.
